physDesc.p: The letter consists of four sheets of paper with typing on each side of the first three and on one side of the last. On the top of each sheet (every other page), excluding the first, there is a page number in the center. There are a few areas where things are crossed out and typewriting or handwriting is added to make changes.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: I think I have at last discovered the mystery of the books not having been received by Constable. The sheets were shipped on the “Anglian” on the 16th of April. Mr. Scaife, who is business manager of Houghton Mifflin’s, has ascertained from the Company that the “Anglian” reached Liverpool safely, in fact that she was due back here yesterday. But Mr. Scaife tells me that he fears the delay occurred on the docks in Liverpool, as he understands that merchandise is piled up all over the docks there, and delivery is dreadfully delayed.

He sent a weekend cable last Friday to Constable, requesting Sadler to look the matter up and, if necessary, to send someone to Liverpool to ferret out the sheets. He says that, if we send any more, they will probably be delayed in the same way, and will certainly not reach Constable so quickly as the original sheets would do. Houghton Mifflin are just as annoyed as you are about it. They realize perfectly the fact that the copyright is lost, and that the delay will occasion a lull in the interest about the book. It is most unfortunate, but I do not believe we can blame the publishers here. It would seem to be a case of conditions in the freight service occasioned by the war. But the bad thing is that Constable, with the exception of Sadler, do not seem to know anything about this business. I think myself that they are the worst firm for selling things in the world.

I am writing a letter to Sadler now, requesting him to do everything in his power to get our book properly on the market. I do not suppose it will be as well put on as it is here, for here I am paying for a lot of separate advertising myself; and that, of course, I cannot do in England as Constable bought their copies of the book outright, and I no longer own them. The venture, therefore, is entirely theirs as far as the English edition is concerned.

The interest here is enormous, as you will see by the clippings I am sending you. The reviews are uniformly bad; but as they are written by people entirely unfitted for the task, both from education and predilection, (the ordinary cheap, hack reviewer in fact,) that does not make much difference. Everybody seems to be talking about it a good deal; but our sale is not any too brilliant, ten copies more however since I last wrote, making 470 in all. Mr. Scaife thinks that the way Ferris Greenslet made a mistake in the first figures was that somehow he counted the figures for the rest of the series. The edition was 750. I think we stand a chance of selling the edition out before the year is over.

I am sending you a beastly slam that we had in “The New Republic,” by a man named Conrad Aiken. He was in London last summer, I believe, and fraternized with Ezra. He writes very poor poetry: old-fashioned and fearfully inverted. I cannot help wondering how much his acquaintance with Ezra has influenced him in jumping on us. It is not a review – merely an article out of a blue sky, and I do not believe will do us much harm. Braithwaite is answering for it for “The New Republic.” The excuse they gave for publishing an article of that kind, when they purport to be my friends, is that they wanted to open a discussion. As Aiken accuses us of interpuffing I did not think that any of us could write the answer. Ferris’s tongue is tied, because he publishes the book, so Braithwaite seemed the only thing, and as he is heart and soul with us and was most anxious to do it, I had to take him faute de mieux.

I took “The Egoist” in to Roger Scaife the other day, rather hoping that he might think well of distributing it; but he was just as much against the plan as Ferris was, although he thinks that, if May Sinclair has really written a good article on us in the next “Egoist,” it might be well to distribute that; so you had better send me 50 copies anyway, possibly more. I had a scheme that the two numbers might be distributed together, and if I can persuade the publishers that that is a wise thing to do, I will send out this May number at the same time with the June.

Remy de Gourmont’s little notice will do us a lot of good here, slight though it is. I have already translated it, and portions of it are going into an advertisement; and Braithwaite will quote it in his defenses for “The New Republic.” The real difficulty here is that there are no prose writers who are interested enough to defend us.

Where is Hueffer? Has he lost interest in us, or have you and he fought, or has he given up writing in the “Outlook?” It is an awful hard row to hoe, Richard, but I think we are getting on. Certainly, we do not lack publicity now. I only long for people to get away from the freak attitude toward us, and take us for the serious and earnest poets that we are.

A man named Kreymborg, who used to edit “The Glebe,” is getting up a little magazine called “Others.” He has written to ask both Fletcher and me for contributions. He tells me that “Pound, Rodker, Cannell, Holley, Williams, and Johns” have responded to his request. Ezra undoubtedly is going to try to run this paper in his own way; so Fletcher and I thought it was just as well to send him contributions at once, so as to give show Ezra a notion that he could not keep us out of it, so we have sent things to him. I do not know whether he has written to you yet, but if I were you, I should send him some of yours and Hilda’s things. His address is: Alfred Kreymborg, Grantwood, New Jersey.

You wrote and asked me about Bruno. They tell me that he is a little Jew, who is frankly out for the money. The Bonis in New York told me that his paper was very poor; and I saw some quotations the other day from it, which were beneath contempt; but I have never seen it myself, and I do not know anything about the man. He seems to be just a fellow who thinks the other young men are making some money out of the new movements, and he wants to try. If I can find out anything more about him, I will let you know.
Do not forget to send me any clippings that come out about us, although I suppose we cannot expect any until the book is issued in England.

Margaret Anderson is still going on, she writes me, though on what I cannot imagine. I have an article on The Poetry Bookshop in the current number, which was written to make up for my having unwittingly hurt Monro’s feelings in my “London Letter.” I tried very hard not to appear to praise him unduly; but I really think he deserves credit for having tried to do something for poetry. His limitations are congenital, and in no way due to a commercial or narrow-minded spirit, I am convinced. I am glad it did not come out until after his review, or people might have thought I was trying to curry favor with him.

I quite agree with you that quiet, unsurperlative speech is the proper way to criticise; but you know what Fletcher is: always extreme, one way or the other, and I cannot get him to write judicially, because it is not his nature.

I am delighted to think that you will defend me in the next number of “The Egoist” because, as I have repeatedly told you, I think your criticism is excellent, honest, and just. Your article on Ezra was a little masterpiece of discrimination.

div.note: French, meaning for want of a better alternative.
Amy Lowell, "The Poetry Bookshop," The Little Review Vol. 2, No. 3 (May, 1915).
